content.title: Hemodynamic Principles in Vascular Surgery
content.summary: Hemodynamics describes the physical principles governing blood flow. Understanding these principles is essential for vascular surgeons to diagnose and treat vascular disease.

fundamental_laws.clinical_relevance: Flow is proportional to radius to the 4th power - small reductions in radius cause large flow reductions
Velocity increases as cross-sectional area decreases, explaining accelerated flow through stenoses
Pressure drops as velocity increases, basis for pressure gradient measurements across stenoses

flow_types.laminar: Parallel layers of blood, minimal energy loss, occurs at normal flow rates
flow_types.turbulent: Chaotic flow, increased energy loss, occurs at high velocities or past stenoses

reynolds_number.threshold: Re > 2000-2300 indicates transition to turbulent flow
reynolds_number.clinical_significance: Turbulent flow creates audible bruits and can be detected on duplex ultrasound

arterial_pressure.systolic: Peak pressure during ventricular contraction (120 mmHg normal)
arterial_pressure.diastolic: Minimum pressure during ventricular relaxation (80 mmHg normal)
arterial_pressure.pulse_pressure: PP = SBP - DBP, affected by stroke volume and arterial compliance

clinical_applications: Duplex velocity criteria for stenosis grading
